info.title: Extreme Campus Controller :: REST API Gateway
info.description:
# Introduction The Extreme Campus Controller REST API Gateway provides a single entry point between the external requesting clients and the multiple internal APIs that help install, access, manage, and extend applications that are supported by the Extreme Campus Controller platform. The Gateway API is based on [RESTful principles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer) and uses standard HTTP methods for requests and responses. API request and response bodies are formatted in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON). You can use any language or library that can submit REST API requests and process JSON to query the Gateway API . Examples of languages and libraries that can build REST clients include: + For Java, the Jersey library provides the reference implementation of JAX-RS, a Java standard for RESTful web services. The implementation includes a client library that can run directly on the JVM. + For Python, the Requests and JSON libraries facilitate REST API applications. + For .Net, the core language provides facilities for submitting HTTP requests, and .Net libraries include a serializer for JSON. + For the Linux shell, Wget and [cURL](https://curl.haxx.se/) can execute REST API calls. Linux shell utilities, like awk and grep, can parse and process JSON. You can also use tools like [Postman](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/postman/fhbjgbiflinjbdggehcddcbncdddomop//%40), an easy-to-use Chrome extension for making HTTP requests.
**Note**: To submit API calls, your RESTful API consuming program needs to have logged in using credentials granting at least read permissions. Any administrator account can be used with the REST API but only user accounts with Full admin credentials can make configuration changes through the REST API. # Authentication and Authorization The Extreme Campus Controller REST API Gateway supports the HTTP bearer authentication scheme in conjuntion with the [OAuth 2.0 protocol](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749) to provide secure authorized access to the API. OAuth is an authorization framework that enables web, mobile, and desktop applications to access protected resources. Bearer authentication (aka token authentication) involves security tokens called bearer tokens. To begin, pass your client login credentials within a POST request to the `management/v1/oauth2/token` endpoint with the following JSON data and structure: ``` { "grantType": "password", "userId": "adminUserId", "password": "adminPassword", "scope": "..." } ``` In exchange for these credentials, the Extreme Campus Controller authorization server issues tokens called bearer tokens that you need to include in the Authorization header when making subsequent REST API calls. Below is a sample response to the token request: ``` { "access_token": "f06f6f285e364e59fd317bd74da9e837", "token_type": "Bearer", "expires_in": 7200, "idle_timeout": 604800, "refresh_token": "3e33d8f724e69024811f1cf5869dbaf7", "adminRole": "FULL" } ``` **Note**: Access tokens have a finite lifetime. The `expires_in` field in the response indicates the lifetime, in seconds, of the access token. For example, a value of 7200 indicates that the access token expires in two hours from the time the response was generated. The API endpoint issues a HTTP 401 Unauthorized status code when it detects an expired token. # API Request Components To construct a REST API request, combine the following components: | Component | Description | |------------| ------------| | The HTTP method |
  • GET: Retrieve data from the server
  • DELETE: Delete a resource from the server
  • POST: Create a new resource on the server
  • PUT: Update an existing resource on the server
| | The base URL of the API | `https://{IP_Address}:5825` where `{IP_Address}` is the IP address of your Extreme Campus Controller server instance. | | The URI to the resource | The resource to create, update, query, or delete. For example, `/management/v1/accesscontrol`. | | Path parameters | These variables are part of the full URL path and are used to point to a specific resource within a collection. For example, `/v1/controllers/{sn}`, where `{sn}` is the path parameter and is substituted with an actual value when making the API call. | | Query string parameters | For most REST GET calls, you can specify one or more optional query parameters on the request URI to filter, limit the size of, and sort the data in an API response. Query string parameters appear after a question mark `(?)` in the endpoint. Each parameter is listed one right after the other with an ampersand `(&)` separating them. The order of the query string parameters does not matter. | | HTTP request headers | The following HTTP headers are supported:
  • Accept: Required for operations with a response body, syntax is `Accept: application/json`
  • Content-Type: Required for operations with a request body, syntax is `Content-Type: application/json`
  • Authorization: Required to pass Bearer token for all API calls
| | JSON request body | Required for most POST and PUT requests. | When you POST or PUT data to the REST API server, set the Content-Type header to `application/json`. It can also be useful to set the following request headers: + `accept: application/json` + `accept-encoding: gzip,deflate,br` + `accept-language: en-US,en;q=0.8,und;q=0.6` # Response Codes The Extreme Campus Controller REST API Gateway returns standard HTTP response codes in addition to JSON-based error messages in the response body to help you identify the source of a problem: | HTTP Code | Description | |------------| ------------| | 200 OK | The request was successful| | 201 Created | The resource was created successfully | | 204 No Content | Success with no response body | | 400 Bad Request | The operation failed because the request is syntactically incorrect or violated schema | | 401 Unauthorized | The authentication credentials are invalid or the user is not authorized to use the API | | 404 Not Found | The server did not find the specified resource that matches the request URL | | 405 Method Not Allowed | The API does not support the requested HTTP method | # Versioning The Extreme Campus Controller API follows the [semantic versioning](https://semver.org/) specification (Major.Minor.Patch). The Major version will be updated whenever we introduce breaking changes. The Minor and Patch versions will be incremented when we add functionality and backward-compatible updates.

requestBody.description: The RequestTokenElement instance to login. The RequestTokenElement instance must have the mandatory attributes like userId, password, and grantType (must be password). It can also have optional attributes.

200.description: The access token if administrator is authenticated and authorized.

delete.summary: Delete an access token

post.summary: Validates OAuth2 access token. Please refer to (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7662) for more details.

token.description: Contains access token information for the user who is requesting external rest endpoints. Two types of tokens are present: a fixed access token is generally used by Extreme Cloud components,  and dynamic access token, which is for the user who is accessing information from the XCA GUI applications.

tokenTypeHint.description: it contains token type hint information. Example: ExtremeAI

requestMethod.description: it contains one of http verb(GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) Example: GET

200.description: Successful operation

successResponse_OK_200.summary: Rest call successful and Introspection Response successful.

successResponse_Unauthroized_401.summary: Rest call successful and Introspection Response Unauthroized(401).

successResponse_ForBidden_403.summary: Rest call successful and Introspection Response Forbidden(403).

successResponse_NotFound_404.summary: Rest call successful and Introspection Response NotFound(404).

parameters.description: Optional radio index of the request. When radioIndex is not provided, it derived from radioMode. For certain APs with dual-band radios both radios may use the same radio mode, but allow different channels and/or maximum Tx power. For example AP510 may operate both radios on 5 Ghz band. macMode.description: A flag to indicate switch over between blacklist/whitelist mode. This attribute cannot be null and must be an integer value of 1 or 2.

macList.description: List of black/white listed MAC addresses. If in whitelist mode, only devices on the list are allowed on the network. If in blacklist mode,  devices on the list are not allowed on network. Whenever a switchover between white/black happens this list is emptied.

AccessLevel.title: AccessLevel
AccessLevel.description: The list of possible access levels for switch administrators that are logged in.

wired.description: Wired clients ports stats. Can be missing if AP has no wired clients stats.

IfRfStatsElement.title: IfRfStatsElement
IfRfStatsElement.description: If AP state is disonnected or no clients associated, all fields are null

rfqi.description: RF Quality Indicator for the Radio, worst is 1 and best is 5.

clientdata.description: Channel Client Data as percentage of the total available medium.

cochannel.description: Co-channel Interference as percentage of the total available medium.

interference.description: No WiFi Interference as percentage of the total available medium.

hardwareType.description:
The model number of the device. The model number is a human readable string and is likely how the device is referred to in customer documentation and data sheets. In the case of APs, the model number provides critical information regarding the regulatory domain the AP is to operate in and provides a way to infer the number of radios in the AP and their capabilities.
Validations : The hardware type value must be between 6 and 32 characters long.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

platformName.description: The platform name of the device

apName.description: Represents the Friendly Name of the access point,(defaults to Serial Number, does not have to be unique).

softwareVersion.description:
Software version number installed on the access point.
Validations : There is no need for a user to enter this so there is no needto validate it.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

hostSite.description:
Site to which the accesspoint is associated
Validations : The Software version must be between 0 and64 characters long.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

description.description:
A user entered string describing this AP. Its contents canbe completely arbitrary. It can be null or empty.
Validations : The description must be between 0 and 255 characters long.

ethPowerStatus.description: The Ethernet Power Status of this AP.

services.description: A list of the names of the services this AP is providing. They could be obtained by looking up its site and getting them from there but it is likely that it will be more efficient to include references to the services directly.

features.description: The list of features supported by this device.

ipAddress.description:
The IP address of one of the AP's wired interfaces. This is the address of the AP on the customer's network.
Validations : It must be Valid IpAddress.

ipNetmask.description:
The IP Netmask of one of the AP's wired interfaces.
Validations : It must be Valid IpAddress.

ipGateway.description:
The IP Gateway address of one of the AP's wired interfaces.
Validations : It must be a valid IP Address.

radios.description:
List of Radios in the access point
Validations : Not null and non-empty list ofRadioElements

supportedCountries.description: List of supported countries for the AP

location.description:
location: a user entered string describing the location of the AP. When a client roams to an AP with a different location, Area Notification is triggered. The Area Notification feature is designed to track client locations within pre-defined areas using either the Location Engine (for more information, see Configuring the Location Engine) or the AP Location field. When the clients change areas, a notification is sent. Location functionality on the AP is useful when access to Extreme Management Center OneView is not available. completely arbitrary. It can be null or empty.
Validations : The description must be between 0 and 32 characters long.

maintainClientSession.description:
maintainClientSession: Enable/Disable, maintain client session in event of poll failure
failure  Select this option (if using a bridged at AP VNS) if the AP should remain active
if a link loss with the controller occurs. This option is enabled by default.

apPersistence.description:
apPersistence: Enable/Disable, restart service in the absence of controller
Select this option (if using a bridged at AP VNS) to ensure the APs radios continue providing service if
the APs connection to the controller is lost. If this option is enabled, it allows the AP to start
a bridged at AP VNS even in the absence of a controller

captureTimeout.description:
captureTimeout: maximum configurable timeout for Real Capture. The Real Capture feature is used to start real capture server on the AP. Default capture server timeout is set to 300 seconds and the maximum configurable timeout is 1 hour. While the capture session is active, the AP interface operates in promiscuous mode. From the Wireshark GUI, set the capture interface to the IP address of the selected AP, and select null authentication. Once Wireshark connects to the AP, the AP's interfaces are listed as available to capture traffic. eth0 is the wired interface, wlan0 is the 5Ghz interface, and wlan1 is the 2.4Ghz interface. You can capture bi-directional traffic on eth0, wifi0, and wifi1. The capture on wifi0 and wifi1 does not include internally generated hardware packets by the capturing AP. The capturing AP does not report its own Beacons, Retransmission, Ack and 11n Block Ack. If this information is needed, perform Real Capture from a second AP that is close by. Make sure both APs are on the same wireless channel. Broadcast an SSID to activate the radios, but do not broadcast the SSID of the AP you are troubleshooting. You do not want the clients to connect to the second capturing AP.
Validations : A valid integer value, the range is between 0 and 3600 seconds

mcastAssembly.description: Indicate if multicast assembly is enabled

home.description: home: enum to indicate if the AP is local or foreign

approvedStatus.description:
approvedStatus: the approved status of the AP
Validations : APPROVED or PENDING

apAntennaModels.description:
apAntennaModels: The AP antenna models (valid only for AP with external antennas)
Validations : None

bcastForDisassoc.description: Indicate if use broadcast of disassociation is enabled

acList.description:
acList: The controller Search List (list of IP addresses) This is not configurable in V1.0, it is set to an empty list. This attribute is read-only
Validations : None

ethMode.description: The mode of the Ethernet interface of the AP

ethSpeed.description: The speed of the Ethernet interface of the AP

lbsEnabled.description: Indicates if location based services is enabled.

proxied.description: Indicates if the AP is not adopted locally, but proxied from controller.

sensorChList.description: List of channels for sensor mode.

bandPreference.description: A flag to enable band steering.

roleIDs.description: Readonly List of Role IDs, assigned to the AP

topologyIDs.description: Readonly List of Topology IDs, assigned to the AP

radioIfList.description: List of WLAN IDs, assigned to the radio.  When radioIfListOvr is true, the list can be set.

cbUser.description: Client Bridge user name. Used when radioIfListOvr=true and 802.1x client bridge enabled.

cbPassword.description: Client Bridge password. Used when radioIfListOvr=true and 802.1x client bridge enabled. The field is write-only. GET operation will always return null for cbPassword

faAuthKey.description: Fabric Attach authentication key. An empty string indicates that the default value is used.

faAuthKeyOvr.description: If present and true, use the faAuthKey value

cbRssThreshold.description: Client bridge RSS threshold for reconnecting to root AP

switchPorts.description: Switch ports where the AP connected.

This POJO represents the person or function that is responsible for administering the customer sites. Three types of administrators exist. A full administrator has the complete ability to configure any ofthe customer sites, networks, devices, or roles, and assign users to roles. A read-only administrator can view and report on the status of the customer sites but cannot make configuration changes. A guest access administrator is typically a non-technical person responsible for creating temporary accounts for guest network access.
User Scopes - scopes field is optional for backward compatibility. However  it is expected to always contain scopes for all resources in request. if  scopes are present in request, it will use the scopes in request to post to backend,  however if scopes missing, the scopes will be derived from user role.

ApRegistrationConfigElement.title: ApRegistrationConfigElement
ApRegistrationConfigElement.description: This POJO represents attributes for registering a device with a controller.

ruOperationMode.description:
ruOperationMode: defines how the controller behaves when registering new, unknown devices. During the registration process, the controllers approval of the APs serial number depends on the security mode that has been set:

Allow all APs to connect --
If the controller does not recognize the registering serial number, a new registration record is automatically created for the AP (if within the MDL license limit). The AP receives a default configuration. The default configuration can be the default template assignment. If the controller recognizes the serial number, it indicates that the registering device is pre-registered with the controller. The controller uses the existing registration record to authenticate the AP and the existing configuration record to configure the AP.

Allow only approved APs to connect (this is also known as secure mode) --
If controller does not recognize the AP, the AP's registration record is created in pending state (if within MDL limits). The administrator is required to manually approve a pending AP for it to provide active service. The pending AP receives minimum configuration only, which allows it to maintain an active link with the controller for future state change. The AP's radios are not configured or enabled. Pending APs are not eligible for configuration operations (VNS Assignment, default template, Radio parameters) until approved.

If the controller recognizes the serial number, the controller uses the existing registration record to authenticate the AP. Following successful authentication, the AP is configured according to its stored configuration record. During the initial setup of the network, Extreme Networks recommends that you select the Allow all Wireless APs to connect option.

This option is the most efficient way to get a large number of APs registered with the controller. Once the initial setup is complete, Extreme Networks recommends that you reset the security mode to the Allow only approved Wireless APs to connect option. This option ensures that no unapproved APs are allowed to connect. For more information, see Configuring Wireless AP Properties. The Allow all Wireless APs to connect option is selected by default.
Validations : A valid integer value, the range is 0 (Allow all APs to connect) or 1 Allow only approved APs to connect

dnsRetries.description:
The number of DNS retry attempts. The number of retries is limitedto 255 for the discovery. The default number of retries is 3.
Validations : A valid integer value, the range is between 1 and 255

dnsDelay.description:
The time delay between each DNS retry attempt. The default delay between retries is 3 seconds.
Validations : A valid integer value, the range is between 1 and 10 seconds

The Secure Shell password for the device.
Validations : password field

PolicyClassOfServiceElement.title: PolicyClassOfServiceElement
PolicyClassOfServiceElement.description:
A class encapsulating the Quality of Service (QoS) settings
that can be applied to a frame. This includes assigning
a rate limit to the traffic when it is ingressing the network,
assigning a rate limit to the traffic when it is egressing the
network, and remarking the layer 2 and layer 3 QoS fields
so that downstream network elements give the frame appropriate
priority handling.

cosName.description:
The unique name of the CoS. This is a mandatory attribute.
Validations : The Cos name must be a Not null and non-empty string between 0 and 255 characters long.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

cosQos.description:
The layer 2 and layer 3 markings to assign to a frame that is subject to this CoS. The member cannot be null but it is possible to set the individual members of cosQoS such that frames subject to this CoS are not remarked. Implementation Note: This should be the actual PolicyQoSMarkingElement not a reference to one of these objects. PolicyQosMarkingElement objects are never processed separately from the class/object in which they are contained.
Validations : Not null and non-empty .

inboundRateLimiterId.description:
The inbound rate limiter to apply to traffic assigned to this CoS. Set inboundLimit to null to assign no rate limiter to inbound traffic. Inbound traffic is traffic from the station entering the network at an edge network element such as an AP. Implementation Note: This is the UUID of PolicyRateLimiterElement
Validations : Valid UUID of inbound RateLimiter.

outboundRateLimiterId.description:
The outbound rate limiter to apply to traffic assigned to this CoS. Set outboundLimit to null to assign no rate limiter to outbound traffic. Outbound traffic is traffic from thenetwork heading out toward the station through an edge network element such asan AP. Implementation Note: This is the UUID of PolicyRateLimiterElement
Validations : Valid UUID of outbound RateLimiter.

mask.description:

255, 254, 252, 248, 240, 224, 192, 128,0.

Default is 255. The value is ignored when tosDscp
is null.

PolicyRateLimiterElement.title: PolicyRateLimiterElement
PolicyRateLimiterElement.description:
A class representing a rate limiter resource on the network element. A rate limiter is assigned to traffic by a policy rule or a role's default action. The rate limiter prevents a station fromsending (or receiving) more than a fixed traffic rate when the network is saturated. If a frame being processed would cause the traffic to exceed the rate limiter, the frame is dropped.
A rate limiter is an actual entity. Different policy rules can share a rate limiter, in which case, all traffic assigned to the rate limiter counts against the limit it is monitoring. For example, if a role assigns rate limiter 'a' set to 500kbps to traffic destined to port 80 and to traffic destined to port 443, then a station assigned to that role can send a maximum of 500kbps of http and https traffic.
Two different rate limiters could be set to the same maximum rate. In that case, the rate limiters act independently off each other. For example, rate limiter 'a' might specify a limit of 500kbps and is applied to traffic destined for port 80; rate limiter 'b' also is set to 500kbps and applies to traffic going to port 443. If a single role uses both rate limiters then it allows stations to which the role is applied to send up to 500kbps to port 80 and up to 500kbps to port 443.
A single station can be assigned up to 8 distinct ingress rate limiters and 8 distinct egress rate limiters.

name.description:
The rate limiter's unique identifier.
Validations : The name must be a not null and non-empty string between 1 and 64 characters long.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

cirKbps.description:
The rate limiter's average rate (CIR) expressed in kbps. Must be a positive integer.
Validations : The value must be between 128 and 25000 or 0 Kbps for unlimited.

SecureTunnelMode.title: SecureTunnelMode
SecureTunnelMode.description:
Provides encryption, authentication, and key management between the AP and/or controllers. Select the desired Secure Tunnel mode: disabled  Secure Tunnel is turned off and no traffic is encrypted. All SFTP/SSH/TFTP traffic works normally.
control(deprecated) - if configure will be changed to controlData.  
controlData - Encrypt control and data traffic between AP & Controller  This mode only benefits routed/bridged@Controller Topologies. An IPSEC tunnel is established from the AP to the controller and all SFTP/SSH/TFTP/WASSP control and data traffic is encrypted. The AP skips the registration and authentication phases, and when selected, the Secure Tunnel Lifetime feature can be configured.
Debug mode  An IPSEC tunnel is established from the AP to the controller, no traffic is encrypted, and all SFTP/SSH/TFTP traffic works normally. The AP skips the registration and authentication phases and when selected, the Secure Tunnel Lifetime.
Note: Changing a Secure Tunnel mode will automatically disconnect and reconnect the AP.

ocsInterval.description: -> Interval between off-channel scans (from 2 - 100 DTIMs). Default setting is 20 DTIMs.

ProfileMeshpointBaseElement.description: This class represents meshpoint configuration per profile.

meshpointId.description: ID of meshpoint, used by the profile

monitorCrm.description: Allows a critical resource (an IP address of a gateway or critical server) to be monitored

monitorPrimaryLink.description: Backhaul Detection: Allows dynamic conversion of meshpoint from root to non-root during a link down event

preferredNeighbor.description: Specifies a preferred neighbor. This setting can be used to bias a device using MCX mesh to utilize a specific neighbor when sending traffic. For example suppose a Non Root AP has multiple neighbors each with a path back to a Root AP. If for some reason the user determines that the chosen neighbor / path back to the Root needs to be changed a preferred neighbor can be configured. To configure a preferred neighbor the user would enter in the IFID (Interface ID) of the neighbors mesh radio into the preferred neighbor field.

preferredRoot.description: Specifies a preferred Root. This setting can be used to bias a device using MCX mesh to utilize a specific Root AP. The user may configure this setting if they determine that a Non Root device should utilize a specific root. This is often used in a linear deployment to help influence Root selection. To configure a preferred Root the user would enter in the MPID of the Roots mesh radio into the preferred Root field.

hysteresisMinTh.description: RSS in dBm of potential neighbor must be above specified value. Value of 0 means no check for RSS.

hysteresisPeriod.description: Potential neighbor candidate must sustain minimum RSS for specified number of seconds.

hysteresisDelta.description: New neightbor candidate must have that many dB better RSS then current neightbor to switch to the new neighbor.

hysteresisSNRDelta.description: Neighbor candicate must sustain specified SNR.

excludeWiredPeer.description: When configuring the meshpoint the Wired Peer Exclusion feature will prevent wired devices from forming a mesh link. Beacons exchanged between wired APs will be dropped by either AP when Wired Peer Exclusion is enabled. An AP that receives beacons from a neighbor that is also wired (as determined by the MINT cost to that AP) will be excluded from forming a mesh link.

meshRoot.description: An AP configured with a meshpoint can either be designated as a Root or Non Root AP. Root APs will have a wired backhaul connected and are considered gateway devices between the wired and wireless network.

costRoot.description: Defines if this AP is cost root. Path for cost calculations will start from this AP.

pathMin.description: Minimum root path metric value to consider a Mesh Point Radio as a candidate in channel evaluation.

pathThreshold.description: Root path metric threshold value. When value exceeds this threshold, an ACS scan is triggered on the mesh point.

tolerancePeriod.description: Maximum time in seconds allowed for a bound mesh point radio to recover.

RoleElement.title: RoleElement
RoleElement.description:
This class represents an instance of Extreme Networks access control policy.
It can be used as a default role for a service or it can be sent to the site and will
only be used if a RADIUS server assigns it explicitly. It must be assigned to a site to be used.

name.description: The role name that is unique across the customer sites.

l2Filters.description: A list of L2 filters associated with the role.

l3Filters.description: A list of L3 filters associated with the role.

l7Filters.description: A list of L7 filters associated with the role.

defaultAction.description:
The default access control action to be applied when none of the rules match the frame. For backward compatbility, defaultAction "ContainToVlan" will be translated to "Allow".
Allowed combinations of defaultAction and topology defaultAction == "allow", topology = <UUID> or topology = null defaultAction == "deny",  topology = <UUID> or topology = null defaultAction == "containToVlan", topology = <UUID>

topology.description:
The default topology to be applied when none of the rules match the frame or the rule that matches the frame has no "containToVlan". Topology can be UUID of an existing, defined topology or, if null, topology is the Network Topology.
For backward compatiblity, if defaultAction == containToVlan, then topology must reference to a defined topology.

defaultCos.description:
The class of service (CoS) to assign to a matchingframe if the role has no rules, or none of the rules match the frame, or if none of the rules that match the frame assign a CoS to the frame. Set this to null to indicate that no CoS will be applied to the frame. In that case the frame's QoS fields will not be remarked and the traffic will not be rate limited in either direction.
Validations : A valid UUID of Cos.

cpIdentity.description:
The identification used by ECP and AP redirecting station to identify each other.
Validations : cpIdentity must be a not null and non-empty string, having maximum of 255 characters, if any of the filter rule has an action as 'FILTERACTION_REDIRECT'.

cpSharedKey.description:
The shared secret (used with identity to sign and encrypt the redirection URL) password that is common to both the controller and the external web server. If you want to encrypt the information passed between the controller and the external Web server.
Validations : cpSharedKey must be a not null and non-empty string, between 16 and 255 characters, if any of the filter rule has an action as 'FILTERACTION_REDIRECT'.

cpDefaultRedirectUrl.description: The redirection URL to which the wireless device user will be directed to after authentication.

SNMPElement.description: Abstract REST Gateway Element - Contains all of the attributes that are common across all elements.

The version of snmp to configure. Options are (Disabled|SNMPv2c|SNMPv3).

If SNMPv2c is selected v2Communities is mandatory and v3Users will be nullified.
If SNMPv3 is selected v3Users is mandatory and v2Communities will be nullified.
IfDisabled is selected v3Users and v3Communities will be nullified.

The SNMPv3 engine ID for the controller running the SNMP agent. The engine ID must be from 5 to 32 characters long.
If SNMPv3 is selected engineId is mandatory and v2Communities will be nullified.

context.description: A description of the SNMP context in V3 mode.

A map of CommunityString and its AccessLevel. If SNMPv2c is selected, v2Communities is mandatory and v3Users will be nullified.
Validations: Community string must be Not Null, Not Empty and in range 1-32.

v3Users is a list of SNMPUser configurations.
If SNMPv3 is selected, v3Users is mandatory and v2Communities will be nullified.

notifications.description: A list of Snmp Notification / Trap destination configuration.

STPElement.title: STPElement
STPElement.description:
This POJO represents the STP configurationon the switch.
XCA will set the name and the port to STP but will use all other STP parameters as default.
All ports have to be listed in both the "spanGuard" and "loopProtect" lists but in one list will be
enabled and in other disabled. It is very rare to enable both protocols on the same port.

enabled.description: Enable/disable Spanning Tree on this device.

loggingLevel.description: The severity for Spanning Tree event logging on this device.

version.description: The Spanning Tree protocol version to run.

bridgePriority.description: By configuring the priority, you make the bridge more or less likely to become the root bridge.

ScheduleInstantElement.title: ScheduleInstantElement
ScheduleInstantElement.description:
This class represents the hour and minute at which an
event occurs.

hour.description:
The hour at which the event starts. The range is 0 to 23, with 0 being midnight in the user's local time zone.
Validations : Integer value between 0 and 23.

minute.description:
The minute within the hour at which the event starts. The range is 0 to 59, with 0 meaning "start on the hour".
Validations : Integer value between 0 and 59.

name.description:
The unique mesh name defined by the user.
Validations : Meshpoint name must be a Not null and non-empty string, between 1 to 64 characters.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

meshId.description:
The Mesh ID is an identifier used to delineate different mesh networks. APs must have the same Mesh ID in order to form mesh links. When a MeshConnex policy is configured and mapped to a radio interface the AP will send out mesh beacons which are used to build the meshpoint neighbor table. When APs have meshpoints configured they exchange beacons and the Mesh ID is checked. If an AP receives a mesh beacon and the Mesh ID does not match its own configured Mesh ID, the beacon is dropped. If the Mesh ID matches then the AP will add an entry for the neighbor in table called the meshpoint neighbor table.
Validations : Mesh ID must be a Not null and non-empty string, between 1 to 32 characters.

root.description:
An AP configured with a meshpoint can either be designated as a Root or Non Root AP. Root APs will have a wired backhaul connected and are considered gateway devices between the wired and wireless network. They are referred to as Meshpoint Root APs. Mesh APs that do not have a backhaul connection are simply referred to as Meshpoints.
While the Root setting can be configured in the meshpoint it is a best practice to define whether or not an AP is Root via a profile or device override

controlVlan.description: UUID of topology that represents control VLAN of the meshpoint. The control VLAN in the meshpoint configuration is used to facilitate Root to Root communication for handoffs. Thus this VLAN only has significance for Meshpoint Roots. When a Meshpoint AP, wireless client, or VMM moves from under one Root to another a bind announcement (BANN) is sent on control VLAN to alert the wired infrastructure and other MeshPoint Roots that the MAC address of a Meshpoint, client devices, or VMM has moved. Also, Layer 2 updates are sent on any VLAN configured on the device that has moved. These broadcast Layer 2 updates ensure that all Roots and Core infrastructure is aware that all client MACs being proxied by the AP that has moved is aware of the change.

neighborTimeout.description: The neighbor idle timeout is the amount of time in seconds that must pass in which no traffic is received from a neighbor before it is declared offline. This is typically set to a low value such as 1-2 minutes such that a non functioning neighbor will have a minimum impact on the mesh network. If a neighboring AP stops sending beacons this timeout will ensure that the neighbor will be removed from the meshpoint neighbor table.

name.description: The unique mesh name defined by the user.

meshId.description: The Mesh ID is an identifier used to delineate different mesh networks.

ApMeshBssidElement.title: ApMeshBssidElement
ApMeshBssidElement.description: This class represents AP mesh point information.

name.description: AP name.

RadioMeshBssidElement.title: RadioMeshBssidElement
RadioMeshBssidElement.description: This class represents radio's related mesh point information.

radioIndex.description: The index value to identify the radio.

MeshpointTreeAccessPointElement.title: MeshpointTreeAccessPointElement
MeshpointTreeAccessPointElement.description: This class represents access point in a meshpoint tree.

name.description: AP name.

ipAddress.description: The IP address of one of the AP's wired interfaces. This is the address of the AP on the customer's network.

parent.description: Serial number of parent AP. If the AP is root, then parent is null

rss.description: Received signal strength in dBm for the connection to the parent.

rxRate.description: User data receive rate in kbps

txRate.description: User data transmit rate in kbps

roamCount.description: How often the uplink has changed.

rss.description: Receive Signal Strength in dBm (-1 to -127)

ServiceElement.title: ServiceElement
ServiceElement.description:
Thisclass represents a set of one or more topologies that also include a network authentication and authorization strategy,
an edge privacy (encryption) policy (open, WPAv2), a default access control policy,
and can be enabled / disabled manually or (eventually) on a schedule.

serviceName.description:
The uniqueservice name defined by the user.
Validations : Service name must be a Not null and non-empty string, between 1 to 64 characters.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

shutdownOnMeshpointLoss.description: Disable service if meshpoint connection is lost

ssid.description:
The SSID. Default value is the same as servicename.
Validations : SSID must be a Not null and non-empty string, between 1 to 32 characters.

unAuthenticatedUserDefaultRoleID.description:
The default role for unauthenticated users. It defaults to the predefined "allow all role". Can be none/not set, in which case it defaults to allow all on the services default topology.
Validations : Not null and valid UUID of Role.

defaultTopology.description:
The topology (VLAN) that traffic should be placed on by default when the role assigned to the station generating the traffic does not specify the VLAN on which to forward traffic. This can be null but it is usually easiestto assign a topology to the service then use roles just to allow or deny specific types of traffic. Default for this attribute is null. Implementation detail: This could just be a String containing the name of a defined topology.
Validations : Valid UUID of Topology.

defaultCoS.description:
The default class of service to assign to frames that are not assigned a CoS by the role assigned to the station generating the traffic. Set this to null to leave unchanged the CoS of frames not assigned a CoS explicitly by the role of the station generating traffic. Default for this attribute is null. Implementation details: This could just be a String containing the name of a defined CoS.
Validations : Valid UUID of Cos.

flexibleClientAccess.description:
Enabling this feature causes the AP to take steps to ensure that fast clients
with content to send get as much airtime as slow clients. When this is off
the AP treats all clients equally and processes packet forwarding requests
on a First-Come-First-Serve basis. By default this feature is disabled.

WpaEnterpriseElement.description:
A class that contains a bag of settings specific to the specific privacy implementation used by this service. privacy is null if the user has selected the privacy = none option.
For the prototype none ("no privacy") and WPAv2-PSK are supported. For release 1.0 WPAv2 Enterprise is supported.

WpaPskElement.description:
A class that contains a bag of settings specific to the specific privacy implementation used by this service. privacy is null if the user has selected the privacy = none option.
For the prototype none ("no privacy") and WPAv2-PSK are supported. For release 1.0 WPAv2 Enterprise is supported.

enabledSchedule.description: The time during which this service is enabled. It is the same time range for each site at which the service is available. Note that most UI's might want to offer simple checklists for time ranges to support (always, weekdays only, office hours only, never, etc. and only expose an exact representation of thefollowing data structure as an advanced option.

suppressSsid.description:
Include the SSID in the beacon frame or suppress it. Setting to true prevents the SSID from being advertised in the beacon. Setting it to false requires the SSID to be included in the beacon advertisements. The default is false. This
should be considered an advanced option for an administrator.

enabled11kSupport.description: Enable support for 802.11k radio management. Setting to true enables the feature and setting to false disables the feature. The feature is disabled by default. When the feature is enabled then support for transmitting the Quiet IE and for the 11k Beacon report are also enabled.Disabling 11k support disables the use of the quiet IE and the 11k Beacon report.

preAuthenticatedIdleTimeout.description:
The number of minutes that the station can remain idle (not transmit payload traffic) before its session is terminated. Applies to stations in the unauthenticated state. Usually this should be set low since many devices associate to whatever wireless networks they see even though the owner is not planning to use the network and may not be aware that there even is a wireless network nearby. The default forthis attribute is 5 minutes. This is an advanced option. An administrator should have to drill down for it in GUI applications.
Validations : Integer value between 5 and 999999.

postAuthenticatedIdleTimeout.description:
The number of minutes that the station can remain idle (not transmit payload traffic) before its session is terminated. Applies to stations that have authenticated to the network. Unless address space is at a premium this can and should be set to a higher value than preAuthenticatedIdleTimeout. The default for this attribute is 30 minutes. This is an advanced option. Anadministrator should have to drill down for it in GUI applications.
Validations : Integer value between 0 and 999999.

sessionTimeout.description:
The maximum number of minutes that a station is allowed to have a session on the network before it is logged out. This applies even when the user is active. Setting this to 0 allows the user to stay on the network without reauthenticating indefinitely. The default for this attribute is0. This value is used as the default maximum session duration for each new session. Session duration timeout values sent from a RADIUS server overrides this value.
Validations : Integer value between 0 and 999999.

uapsdEnabled.description:
Unscheduled Automatic Power Save Delivery (U-APSD) also known as WMM power save. Set to true
to enable U-APSD andfalse to disable. The default for this setting is true (enabled). This is an
advanced setting that most users will never need to change. It is configurable only because
some client devices do not implement u-apsd correctly and run into trouble on networks using
it.

admissionControlVideo.description:
This feature is only available if admission control is enabled for Voice. With admission control, clients
are forced to request admission to use the high priority access categories in both inbound and outbound directions.
Admission control protects admitted traffic against new bandwidth demands.Select to provide distinct thresholds for VI (video)

admissionControlVoice.description:
Select to enable admission control forVoice. With admission control, clients are forced to request admission
to use the high priority access categories in both inbound and outbound directions. Admission control protects
admitted traffic against new bandwidth demands.

admissionControlBestEffort.description:
Select to enable Global Admission Control for Best Effort, If the client does not support admission control for the
access category that requires admission control, the traffic category will be downgraded to lower access category that does
not have Mandatory Admission control. For example, if admission control is required for video, and client does not support
admission control for video, traffic will be downgraded to Best Effort (BE)

admissionControlBackgroundTraffic.description:
Select to enable  Global Admission Control for Background Traffic, This feature is only available if admission control is enabled for Background.
With admission control, clients are forced to request admission to use the high priority access categories in both inbound and outbound
directions. Admission control protects admitted traffic against new bandwidth demands

vendorSpecificAttributes.description:
In addition to the standard RADIUS message, you can include Vendor Specific Attributes (VSAs).
The Extreme Networks IdentiFi Wireless authentication mechanism provides seven VSAs for RADIUS and
other authentication mechanisms (Vendor Specific Attributes).

authenticatedUserDefaultRoleID.description: Default role Id for authenticated user

mbatimeoutRoleId.description: Mac based authentication timeout Role id

bypassOnboardingEnabled.description: Determines if the enabled bypass onboarding authentication is done on a 3rd-party RADIUS server. The default is false.

proxied.description: Indicates if the service is not adopted locally, but proxied from controller.

clientToClientCommunication.description: Enabling this feature causes the AP to allow MU to MU communication

includeHostname.description: Controls the AP hostname presence in the beacons.

mbo.description: Enables Agile Multiband feature, that enables Wi-Fi devices to better respond to changing Wi-Fi network conditions. Improved resource utilization helps balance Wi-Fi network load, increase capacity, and provide end users the best possible Wi-Fi experience.

oweCompanion.description: The uuid of the open or OWE network service. "oweCompanion" will be "null", if not set.

oweAutogen.description: Auto generate the OWE network for transition mode

name.description: Up to 252B UTF-8 string.

naiRealms.description: Network Access Identifier realms. The NAI Realm is a FQDN of the service provider (SP).

items.description: 3B or 5B binary internal representation. User interfaces use the string representation (e.g. AABBCCDDEE).

id.description: 3B or 5B binary internal representation. User interfaces use the string representation (e.g. AABBCCDDEE).

cellularNetwork3gpp.description: Identifies a public land mobile network (PLMN).

mcc.description: Mobile Country Code. Consists of 3 decimal digits (0 to 9). List found at: http://www.3gpp.org/

mnc.description: Mobile Network Code. Consists of 2 or 3 decimal digits (0 to 9). List found at: http://www.3gpp.org/

redirectionUrl.description: FQDN of the redirection URL. NULL if not configured.

name.description: Up to 252B UTF-8 string.

protocol.description: IP protocol number available from www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers

methods.description: Encoded OSU methods and their priorities. Priority is given by the index/position in the array.

icon.description: Contains the icon file (*.png format) base64 encoded. NULL if not configured.

name.description: Up to 252B UTF-8 string.
Up to 252B UTF-8 string.

RoamingAssistPolicyElement.title: RoamingAssistPolicyElement
RoamingAssistPolicyElement.description: When roamingAssistPolicy=null, roaming assist is disabled. When roamingAssistPolicy={ detectionThreshold: -90 }, roaming assist is enabled.

OweElement.title: OweElement
OweElement.description: A class that contains setting of OWE for IEEE 802.11 wireless networks

WepElement.title: WepElement
WepElement.description: A class that contains setting for Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) a security algorithm for IEEE 802.11 wireless networks

passPhrase.description: password phrase - length base on keyLength

mode.description:
Whether to support legacy clients that can only
use TKIP. Auto - means use AES when possible
but use TKIP for clients that only speak TKIP. AES
means only use AES encryption, even if it means a
TKIP only client cannot access the network. Default
is "auto" but "aes" is more secure.

pmfMode.description:
Whether to encrypt a subset of management frame traffic as
specified by 802.11w. The default is enabled.

fastTransitionEnabled.description:
Aboolean indicating whether Fast Transition should be enabled
for this WLAN support. Fast Transition allows stations using
802.1x protected connections to rapidly roam between APs. Fast Transition
requires support from the client to be effective. The default is
to disable this option.
roam between APs

fastTransitionMdId.description:
MDID identifies the mobility domain (set of APs) in which 802.11r
fast roaming procedure can be used.

mode.description:
Whether to support legacy clients that can only
use TKIP. Auto - means use AES when possible
but use TKIP for clients that only speak TKIP. AES
means only use AES encryption, even if it means a
TKIP only client cannot access the network. Default
is "auto" but "aes" is more secure.

pmfMode.description:
Whether to encrypt a subset of management frame traffic as
specified by 802.11w. The default is enabled.

keyHexEncoded.description:
Indicates whether the shared key isa plain text string or
an ASCII-encoded hex string which could include hex
representations of binary data.

presharedKey.description:
The shared key used by all mesh APs. The length must be between 8 and 64 characters inclusive.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric and special characters

monday.description:
Thetime that a service starts and stops on Mondays.
If start time == stop time then the service is disabled all day.

tuesday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Tuesdays.
If start time == stop time then the service is disabled all day.

wednesday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Wednesdays.
If start time == stoptime then the service is disabled all day.

thursday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Thursdays.
If start time == stop time then the service is disabled all day.

friday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Fridays.
If start time == stop time then the service is disabled all day.

saturday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Saturdays.
If start time == stop time then the service is disabled all day.

sunday.description:
The time that a service starts and stops on Sundays.
If start time== stop time then the service is disabled all day.

timeZone.description:
The time zone in which the service time is meant to apply. Will be converted to UTC for scheduling purposes within EXOL.
Validations : Not null and non-empty string.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

start.description:
The time at which the service starts.
Validations : Not null, non-empty and a valid ScheduleInstantElement value as string.

stop.description:
The time at which the service stops.
Validations : Not null, non-empty and a valid ScheduleInstantElement value as string.

This class represents the reporting data for a service.
It contains usage data for a specific service like usage statistics, outstanding alerts,
device distribution statistics, application distribution statistics, floor plan, busiest access points
and busiest users of a site.

The unique name of the VLAN. Must not be null or empty.

A VLAN ID between 1 to 4094.

AAAPolicyElement.description: This class represents a AAA Policy

NAS IP Address
The IP address of Network Access Server (NAS).

includeFramedIp.description: Flag to include the Framed-IP attribute in the RADIUS access request.

SiteElement.title: SiteElement
SiteElement.description:
This class represents a site which is a single, topologically contiguous location. A site consists of a set of Extreme Online
Edge Devices and set of networks offered by the devices. A site must have atleast one network.

siteName.description:
A string that uniquely identifies a location
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

country.description: The name of the country in which the site and its devices are deployed. This is an optional attribute so can be null.

timezone.description:
The name of the time zone in which the site and its devices are located. The string must be one of the official time zone strings listed in the file "zone1970.tab" available from IANA at www.iana.org in the file https://www.iana.org/time-zones/repository/releases/tzdata2015e.tar.gz. This field is mandatory.
Validations : Not null and non-empty, valid time zone string

deviceGroups.description: The list of device groups associated with this site.

switchDeviceGroups.description: The list of switch device groups associated with this site.

switchSerialNumbers.description:
The list of switches in the site. It return only contains the serial numbers of the switches.
Valid character set : Alphanumeric, special characters except semi-colon, colon and ampersand

stpEnabled.description: A flag to enable STP globally per site.

snmpConfig.description: The SNMP configuration created for the site.

features.description: The list of features supported by this site. This list can be used by GUI to display or hide certain widgets.

proxied.description: Indicates if the site is not adopted locally, but proxied from controller.

enforceVersion.description:
Select enforce version to enforce which ap version to be allowed in the site. Default is major. Options are, full    Allow adoption only when the first four octets of the firmware
        versions match, e.g. 5.1.0.0
major   Allow adoption only when the first two  octets of the firmware
        versions match, e.g. 5.1
minor   Allow adoption only when the first three octets of the firmware
        versions match, e.g. 5.1.1
none    Allow adoption between any versions strict  Allow adoption only when the firmware versions are exactly the same,
        e.g. 5.1.0.0-123456X

preferredAffinity.description: Select preferred connection point for APs, assigned to this site.

useRadiusAuthentication.description: A flag to identify if Radius Authentication is used

useRadiusAccounting.description: A flag to identify if Radius Accounting is used

ipAddress.description: The IP address of the radius server.

sharedSecret.description: This is the shared secret between the authenticator (the access point) and the authentication server (RADIUS).

The RADIUS Authentication Retries.
valid range 1 - 32 retries.

authTimeout.description:
The RADIUS Authentication Timeout.
valid range 1 - 360 seconds.

port.description: The port on which the RADIUS IP listens for accounting.

totalRetries.description:
The RADIUS Authentication Retries.
valid range 1 - 32.

timeout.description:
The RADIUS Authentication Timeout.
valid range 1 - 360 seconds.

SwitchElement.description: This class represents an Extreme edge switch.

serialNumber.description:
The globally unique serial numberof the device being registered. The serial number is represented as a string. The actual length and format of the string depends on the type of device being registered. This attribute of the device must not be null. Validations: Not required, as it is a read-only attribute.

The MAC address of the edge switch being managed. This attribute is read-only.

softwareVersion.description:
The version number of the software installed on the switch.
Validations: Not required, as it is a read-only attribute.

hostSite.description:
The site with which the switch is associated.

switchType.description:
The model number of the device. The model number is a human-readable string and is likely how the device is referred to in customer documentation and data sheets.

systemName.description:

DeviceAdoptionRuleElement.description: This class represents one DeviceAdoptionRule and customer can have 0 or more device adoption rules.

isIpAddressPrivate.description: It represents whether ipAddress parameter is private or public ip address. By default it is is false. XCA uses default value as false,it not received in the request. when it is false, device adoption rule matches the device public ip address(NATed). when it is true, device adoption rule matches the device private IP address.

siteId.description: Specifies which site a device should be assigned when criteria match. When siteId is null, siteName is used as a pattern.

siteName.description:
When siteId is null, siteName is used as pattern with substitution strings: $DNS-SUFFIX[x:y]  uses substring of DNS suffix of AP, from character at position x to character at position y. y has to be equals or larger than x. DNS suffix is FQDN with hostname part removed. For example, if AP reports FQDN ap27u18.cath.extremenetworks.com, then DNS suffix is cath.extremenetworks.com. $FQDN[x:y]  uses substring of FQDN/hostname of AP, from character at position x to character at position y. y has to be equals or larger than x. For example, if user specifies that device will be assigned to site named SITE-$FQDN[5:7], and AP reports its hostname as ap27u18.cath.extremenetworks.com, then AP will be assigned to site named SITE-u18.
The following variants of substitution strings can be used:
  x The whole string, for example: SITE-$FQDN
  x Substring from beginning to a particular index, for example: SITE-$FQDN[:3]
  x Substring from a particular index to the end, for example: SITE-$FQDN[5:]
  x Substring from index x to index y (x <= y), for example: SITE-$FQDN[3:5]

If such site doesnt exist, an error will be logged and XCA will continue evaluation of adoption rules.

devGrName.description: Specifies name of device group a device should be assigned when criterias match. devGrName can use substitution strings, see "siteName" for description of substitution strings.

redirectTo.description: When action==Redirect, specifies IPv4 address or FQDN of new adopter.

DeviceAdoptionRuleAction.title: DeviceAdoptionRuleAction
DeviceAdoptionRuleAction.description: Allow: let device adopt and assign it to a site and/or device group Deny: do not allow device to adopt Redirect: do not allow device to adopt, and redirect the device to another management entity

DeviceAdoptionCategory.title: DeviceAdoptionCategory
DeviceAdoptionCategory.description: Category of device, where adoption rule applies to.

password.description: Retruns only on creation of the application key.

user.description: User that created to Application Key.

Hostname.description: hostname is visible in beacons transmition.  The hostname rules will be enforced, based on the following regular expression: r'\A(([a-z0-9](?:[a-z0-9-.]*[a-z0-9])))\Z The hostname will be generated based on the AP name, by removing any unsupported characters, based on the above regular expression. The following restrictions will apply for the hostname size: - for legacy WING APs and WING7 APs (both personalities): XCA has a 64 characters limit for the AP name, that will translate to the same maximum hostname length. - for legacy Identifi (39xx): the hostname will be kept at maximum 32 characters
